article_title: Texas could face health insurance sticker shock for 2016
article_text:
Texas could face health insurance sticker shock for 2016 Insurance firms say new clients forcing increase

Photo: DOUG MILLS, STF Demonstrators celebrate the U.S. Supreme Court's decision in June...

The U.S. Supreme Court last month may have eased some of the fear surrounding the fate of the Affordable Care Act, but one anxiety was quickly replaced with another as some health insurers now have asked to raise rates by more than 30 percent in Texas and across the country.

article_metadata.description: The U.S. Supreme Court last month may have eased some of the fear surrounding the fate of the Affordable Care Act, but one anxiety was quickly replaced with another as some health insurers now have asked to raise rates by more than 30 percent in Texas and across the country.  The companies justify the hikes by citing rising medical and drug prices as well as saying they previously underestimated the true costs of insuring tens of millions of new customers, many of whom had delayed treatment or were sicker than anticipated.  In Texas, the biggest rate increases for plans sold through the federal marketplace are being sought by Scott & White Health Plan, which has said it needs a 32.4 percent increase on average in its individual silver plan and a 31 percent increase in its bronze plan; Humana, which is proposing to raises one of its individual plans by an average 29.73 percent; and Blue Cross Blue Shield of Texas, which is asking for a 19.97 percent hike for its Blue Advantage HMO individual plan.  "Just when we thought we were out of the woods, we now have to worry about whether private health insurers will deliver affordable rates - which is what the law is supposed to be all about," said Vivian Ho, a health-care economist at Rice University's Baker Institute who has been tracking the implementation of the Affordable Care Act.  Under the Affordable Care Act, any insurer - both inside and outside the federal or state exchanges - that proposes an increase of more than 10 percent for its small group and individual plans must make the request public on the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services website.  [...] it went mostly unnoticed as much of the country remained focused on the U.S. Supreme Court and its heavily anticipated decision on whether insurance customers in Texas and other states that had not set up state-run exchanges could keep federal subsidies to make coverage affordable.  Any discussion of average rate increases will be misleading to the consumer as the rate changes individuals may personally receive are impacted by a host of factors, officials at Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Texas said in an email to the Chronicle.  [...] it is at the federal level that Health and Human Services conducts a review of rate filings by Texas insurers for use on the ACA exchanges.  With those plan costs still in flux - some low-cost plans may go up while others go down - it is likely that for 2016 "many consumers will need to change plans," said Cheryl Fish-Parcham, private insurance program director for Families USA, a national health care advocacy group for consumers  Many are watching the 2016 rate increase process with concern, worrying that as prices rise consumers might not know to shop around or simply not want the hassle of switching to a less expensive plan.  Under the law, an insurance company must pay out 80 percent of the money it takes in on premiums, leaving just 20 percent for administrative costs and profits.
article_metadata.author.name: By Jenny Deam
